item.name: Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee

item.title: Accountant, Compliance, and Enforcement Staffing Act of 2003

item.name: Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee

item.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs.
For further action, see H.R. 658, which became Public Law 108-44 on 7/3/2003.

summary.text:
Accountant, Compliance, and Enforcement Staffing Act of 2003 - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to except from the competitive service all accountant, economist, and securities compliance examiner positions in the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Declares that an employee in the competitive service whose position becomes excepted shall be considered as continuing in the competitive service as long that employee continues to be employed in that position.

bill.title: Accountant, Compliance, and Enforcement Staffing Act of 2003

item.title: Accountant, Compliance, and Enforcement Staffing Act of 2003

A bill to provide the protection of investors, increase confidence in the capital markets system, and fully implement the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 by streamlining the hiring process for certain employment positions in the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Accountant, Compliance, and Enforcement Staffing Act of 2003

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
